Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports three meetings of the Lehigh-Harvard Conference on Geometry and Topology with the first one taking place at Lehigh University on May 24-26. The conference is held at Lehigh University two years out of three, and at Harvard University every third year.

The conference brings leading researchers of national and international stature in geometry and topology to discuss their latest work. The conference makes it possible for the community of geometers and topologists from the region and around the country to learn the most recent developments, to meet with each other and to share mathematics. The conference is also dedicated to the development and training of of graduate students and young faculty in geometry and topology. An important component of the conference is to attract and help graduate students and recent Ph.Ds to come from all over the country to learn and interact with principal speakers and other senior mathematicians; there are also ample chance for them to present their research results when the conference is held at Lehigh. Participation by women and minorities will be actively sought and encouraged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Journal of Differential Geometry (JDG), Lehigh University, and Harvard University jointly organize the annual Geometry and Topology Conference. It is held at Lehigh University two years out of three, and at Harvard University every third year. The purpose of the Lehigh-Harvard Geometry and Topology Conference is to bring leading researchers of national and international stature in geometry and topology to discuss the forefront of these fields and to interact with other mathematicians, including graduate students and post-docs, from the region and around the country.

During the period of NSF Award 1327329 (05/01/2013-05/31/2017), five Geometry and Topology Conferences were held: three conferences were held at Lehigh University (in 2013, 2015, and 2016), while two conferences were held at Harvard (in 2014 and 2017). The majority of the funding from the NSF award was used to support the participation by graduate students, recent PhDs, and mathematicians in underrepresented groups.

These conferences brought leading researchers of national and international stature in geometry and topology to present their latest research findings and to interact with other mathematicians, including graduate students and junior faculty, from around the country. These events helped to promote and stimulate further research developments in differential geometry, geometric analysis, topology, and related fields. A conference proceedings of the 2017 Harvard conference will be published in 2018.

These conferences also made it possible for the community of geometers and topologists from the region and around the country to learn the most recent developments, and to meet with each other to discuss mathematics. The conferences also helped the training of graduate students and young faculty: they had ample opportunities to interact with the invited speakers and other senior mathematicians. Especially when the conference was held at Lehigh, in addition to attending invited lectures by leading experts, graduate students and recent PhDs were able to present their own research work at the conference.
